page.title: 10CODDINGTON - ECOLOGY
page.content: The Jubilee Plantation is 2.7 acres of land which became a {conservation} area in 1977, Jubilee Year. Formerly a rubbish dump, Mr.& Mrs.G.Page obtained permission from the Parish Council to designate the land as a{Nature Reserve Many saplings of oak, wild cherry, field maple, sycamore, whitebeam and crab-apple planted seven years ago survive today. Great-tits, sparrows, yellow-hammers, whitethroats, wrens, thrushes and blackbirds nest there. The caterpillars of red admiral and small tortoiseshell butterflies feed on the nettles. Tufted vetch, speedwell, shepherd's purse and pepperwort grow freely. Mr.& Mrs.G.Page live next to the plantation caring for sick and injured birds, many of which swim on the Medieval moat, listed as an {Ancient {Monument}.
